title: Jim and Holly Akenson Interview, Part One
creator: Jack Kredell
description: Jack Kredell interviewing Jim and Holly Akenson, researchers who first went to the Taylor Wilderness Research Station in 1982. In part one, they discuss talk what attracted them to the research station in 1982, the transitional period between the Idaho Primitive Area to the Frank Church River of No Return Wilderness, living at the Taylor Ranch. In part two they discuss the impact of the '00 wildfire on the research station, how that fire season changed their views.

title: Andrew Armstrong
creator: Jack Kredell
description: Jack Kredell interviews Andrew Armstrong, facilities superintendent at the Taylor Wilderness Research Station. Andrew talks about what attracted him to his job at Taylor Ranch, what he does, and what life is like in the area.
bio: Andrew Armstrong lives full time at Taylor Ranch as station superintendent beginning in 2021.
full bio: Andrew Armstrong lives full time at Taylor Ranch as station superintendent beginning in 2021. He received a BS in Environmental Engineering from Cal Poly San Luis Obispo. Previously, he has worked in renewable power and net zero construction in Idaho and overseas. He received his PhD in Materials Science from Boise State University in 2020. Andrew first visited Taylor Ranch back in 1999, while a youngster working for his family’s trail building and backcountry Airstrip construction company. Andrew supports scientific efforts at Taylor while keeping the facility running and doing related ranch work. The station is co-managed by Andrew’s dog, Josie, and three cats—Little One, Queen Jane, Blacky—along with a beloved assortment of horses, mules, and chickens.
subject: wildlife;researchers;murder;rivers;

title: Gary Koehler
creator: Jack Kredell
description: Jack Kredell interviews Gary Koehler, a wildlife biologist, about his experiences with the Taylor Wilderness Research Station. Gary became interested in the research station in 1969 and studied bobcats and their interactions with wolves and cougars.
bio: Taylor Ranch, at the center of The Frank Church River of No-Return Wilderness, is what drew me to Idaho from neighboring Washington. One of the largest Wilderness areas in the contiguous U.S. and Dr. Maurice Hornocker’s research on this Wilderness’ enigmatic carnivore, the Mountain Lion, sealed its allure.
full bio: Taylor Ranch, at the center of The Frank Church River of No-Return Wilderness, is what drew me to Idaho from neighboring Washington. One of the largest Wilderness areas in the contiguous U.S. and Dr. Maurice Hornocker’s research on this Wilderness’ enigmatic carnivore, the Mountain Lion, sealed its allure. The serendipity of place and my fortuitous introduction to Maurice led to my pursuit for PhD Studies at Taylor Ranch on Bobcat ecology during the early 1980s. This pristine natural laboratory was a perfect setting for unraveling the mystery of this little cat where their populations and environment were minimally impacted by man.  After receiving my degree and intrigued to explore more remote areas of the world and their native felids I ventured to the Serengeti-Mara ecosystem of Kenya to study African lions and later to Mongolia and Nepal to study snow leopards. Returning to Washington I embarked on a suburban study area, where cougars, otherwise known as Mountain Lions, and humans appeared to co-exist with few conflicts. This research integrated the community and the Cle Elum Public Schools into Project CAT (Cougars and Teaching).

title: Grace Peven
creator: Jack Kredell
description: Jack Kredell interviews Grace Peven, a PhD researcher at the University of Idaho. Grace talks about her research, the impact of climate change on the wilderness region, the landscape around the research station.
bio: Grace Peven is currently a PhD student in the Water Resources program whose research investigates how spring ecosystems in the Big Creek watershed contribute to climate change and wildfire resilience.
full bio: Grace Peven is currently a PhD student in the Water Resources program whose research investigates how spring ecosystems in the Big Creek watershed contribute to climate change and wildfire resilience. Despite their small size, springs provide disproportionately large ecological benefits to the surrounding landscape through the consistent flow of groundwater. Springs are difficult to study because of their small size on the landscape and remote access. Consequently, it is estimated that over 50% of springs in the western United States are unmapped, and in wilderness areas, the percentage is significantly less. This has resulted in a limited understanding of how spring ecosystems contribute to landscape scale ecological function, biodiversity, and climate change resilience. Grace’s research involves traversing the mountains around TWRS to map springs, measure the stability of spring flow in response to changing snowpack, and understand how springs facilitate forest regeneration following wildfire.
subject: rivers;research;springs;ecology
